sp.l: Nay hand him lords, he is your kinsman too.
Archas my son, of fair Calisto born,
I hope fair Juno it offends not you,
It was before your time.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.l: She was a strumpet.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: She shall be a star.
And all the Queens and beauteous maids on earth
That are renowned for high perfections,
We'll woe and win, we were born to sway and rule.
Nor shall the name of wife be curb to us.
Or snaffle in our pleasures. Beauteous Io,
And fair Europa, have by out transhapes,
And guiles of love already been deflowered,
Nor lives she that is worthy our desires,
But we can charm with courtship. Royal brothers
What news of note is rumoured in those realms,
Through which you made your travels?

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: Have you heard
Of great Acrisius, the brave Argos King,
And of his daughter Danae.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: His renown,
And her fair beauty oft hath pierced our ears.
Nor can we be at peace, till we behold
That face fame hath so blazed on. What of her?

sp.speaker: Nept.
sp.l: Of her enclosure in the Darreine tower,
Girt with a triple mure of shining brass.
Have you not heard?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: But we desire it highly.
What marble wall, or adamantine gate,
What fort of steel, or castle forged from brass,
Love cannot scale? or beauty not break through?
Discourse the novel neptune.

sp.speaker: Nept.
sp.l: Thus it was.
The Queen of Argos going great, the King
Sends (As the custom is) to th'oracle,
To know what fortunes shall betide the babe.
Answer's returned by Phoebus and his priests:
The Queen shall child a daughter beautiful,
Who when she grows to years, shall then bring forth
A valiant princely boy, yet such a one
That shall the King his grandsire turn to stone.
Danae is born, and as she grows to ripeness,
So grew her father's fear: and to prevent
His ominous fate pronounced by th'oracle,
He moulds this brazen tower, impregnable
Both for the seat and guard: yet beautiful
As is the gorgeous palace of the sun.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Ill doth Acrisius to contend and war
Against th'unchanging fates, I'll scale that towers:
Or rain down millions in a golden shower.
I long to be the father of that babe,
Begotten on Danae, that shall prove so brave,
And turn the dotard to his marble grave.
'Tis cast already: fate be thou my guide,
Whilst for this amorous journey I provide.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But is the lady there immured, and closed
From all society and sight of man?

sp.speaker: Nept.
sp.l: So full of jealous fears is King Acrisius,
That, save himself, no man must near the fort.
Only a guard of beldames passed their lusts,
Unsensible of love, or amorous pity,
Partly by bribes hired, partly curbed with threats,
are guard unto this bright imprisoned dame.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: Too pitiless, and too obdures the King,
To cloister beauty from the sight of man.
But this concerns not us.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: That fort I'll scale,
Though in attempting it be death to fail.
Brothers and princes, all our courts rarities
Lie open to your royal'st entertainment
Yet pardon me, since urgence calls me hence
To an enforced absence. Nay Queen Juno
You must be pleased, the cause imports us highly.
Feast with these princes till our free return.
Attendance lords, we must descend in gold.
Or you imprisoned beauty ne'er behold.
sp.stage: Enter four old beldames, with other women.

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.p: Here's a coil to keep fire and tow asunder. I wonder the King should shut his daughter up so close: for any thing I see, she hath no mind to a man.

sp.speaker: 2. Beld.
sp.p: Content yourself, you speak according to your age and appetite. We that are full fed may praise fast. We that in our heat of youth have drunk our bellyfuls, may deride those that in the heat of their bloods are athirst. I measure her by what I was, not by what I am. Appetite to love never fails an old woman, till cracking of nuts leaves her. When Danae hath no more teeth in her head then you and I, I'll trust a man in her company, and scarce then: for if we examine ourselves, we have even at these years, qualms, and rheums, and devises comes over our stomachs, when we but look on a proper man.

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.p: That's no question, I know it by myself, and whilst I stand centinel, I'll watch her for that I warrant her.

sp.speaker: 2. Bel.
sp.p: And have we not reason, considering the penalty?

sp.speaker: 1. Bel.
sp.p: If any stand centinel in her quarters, we shall keep quarter here no longer. If the Princess miscarry we shall make gunpowder, and they say an old woman is better for that then saltpetre.

sp.speaker: 3. Beld.
sp.l: The 'larm bell rings,
It should be K. Acrisius by the sound of the clapper.

sp.speaker: 4. Beld.
sp.l: Then clap close to the gate and let him in.

sp.speaker: Acri.
sp.l: Ladies well done: I like this providence
And careful watch o'er Danae: let me find you
Faithless, you die, be faithful and you live
Eternised in our love. Go call her hither,
Be that your charge: the rest keep watchful eye
On your portcullised entrance, which forbids
All men, save us, free passage to this place.
See! Danae is descended. Fair daughter
How do you brook this palace?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Like a prison:
What is it else? you give me golden fetters,
As if their value could my bondage lessen.

sp.speaker: Acri.
sp.l: The architecture's sumptuous, and the building
Of cost invaluable, so rich a structure
For beauty, or for state, the world affords not.
Is not thy attendance princely, like a Queen's?
Are not all these thy vassals to attend?
Are not thy chambers fair, and richly hung?
The walks within this barricadoed mure
Full of delight and pleasure for thy taste
And curious palate, all the chiefest cates
Are from the furthest verges of the earth
Fetch't to content thee. What distasts thee then?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: That which alone is better than all these,
My liberty. Why am I cloistered thus,
And kept a prisoner from the sight of man?
What hath my innocence and infancy
Deserved to be immured in brazen walls?
Can you accuse my faith, or modesty?
Hath any loose demeanour in my carriage
Bred this distrust? hath my eye played the rioter?
Or hath my tongue been lavish? have my favours
Unvirginlike to any been profuse,
That it should breed in you such jealousy,
Or bring me to this durance?

sp.speaker: Acri.
sp.l: None of these.
I love my Danae. But when I record
the oracle, it breeds such fear in me,
That makes this thy retainment.

sp.speaker: Danae.
sp.l: The oracle?
Wherein unto the least of all the gods
Hath Danae been unthankful, or profane,
To bondage me that am a Princess free,
And votaress to every deity?

sp.speaker: Acri.
sp.l: I'll tell thee lady. The unchanging mouth
Of Phoebus, hath this oracle pronounced,
That Danae shall in time child such a son
That shall Acrisius change into a stone.

sp.speaker: Danae.
sp.l: See your vain fears. What less could Phoebus say?
Or what hath Danae's fate deserved in this?
To turn you into stone; that's to prepare
Your monument, and marble sepulchre.
The meaning is, that I a son shall have,
That when you die shall bear you to your grave.
Are you not mortal? would you ever live?
Your father died, and to his monument
You like a mourner did attend his hearse.
What you did to your father, let my son
Perform to you, prepare your sepulchre.
Or shall a stranger bear you to your tomb,
When from your own blood you may store a prince
To do those sacred rights: or shall vain fears
Cloister my beauty, and consume my years?

sp.speaker: Acri.
sp.l: Our fears are certain, and our doom as fixed
As the decrees of gods. Thy durance here
Is with limit endless. Go attend her
Unto her chamber, there to live an anchoress
And changeless virgin, to the period
Of her last hour. And you, to whom this charge
Solely belongs, banish all womanish pity:
Be deaf unto her prayers, blind to her tears,
Obdure to her relenting passions.
Should she (As heaven and th'oracle forbid)
By your corrupting loose that precious gem
we have such care to keep and lock safe up:
Your lives are doomed. Be faithful we desire,
And keep your bodies from the threatened fire.

sp.speaker: 1, Beld.
sp.p: Heaven be as chary of your highness' life, as we of Dana's honour. Now if she be a right woman, she will have a mind only to lose that, which her father hath such care to keep. There is a thing that commonly sticks under a woman's stomach.

sp.speaker: 2. Beld.
sp.p: What do we talking of things? there must be no meddling with things in this place, come let us set our watch, and take our lodgings before the Princess chamber,
sp.stage: Enter Jupiter like a pedlar, the clown his man, with packs at their backs.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Sirrah, now I have sworn you to secrecy attend your (Charge

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Charge me to the mouth, and till you give fire I'll not of.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Thou knowest I have stuffed my pack with rich jewels, to purchase one jewel worth all these.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: If your precious stones were set in that jewel it would be brave wearing.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: If we get entrance, sooth me up in all things: and if I have recourse to the Princess, if at any time thou seest me whisper to her, find some trick or other to blind the beldame's eyes.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: She that hath the best eyes of them all, I have a trick to make her nose stand in her light.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: No more K. Jupiter but goodman pedlar, remember that

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I have my memorandums about me. As I can bear a pack, so I can bear a brain, and now I talk of a pack, though I know not of the death of any of your friends, I am sorry for your heaviness.

sp.speaker: Iup,
sp.l: Love and my hopes do make my load seem light,
This wealth I will unburden in the purchase
Of you rich beauty. Prithee ring the bell,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Nay do you take the rope in your hand for luck's sake. The moral is, because you shall ring all-in.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: I care not if I take thy counsel.

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.p: To the gate, to the gate, and know who 'tis ere you open.

sp.speaker: 2. Beld.
sp.p: I learned that in my youth, still to know who knocked before I would open.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Save you gentle matrons: may a man be so bold as ask what he may call this rich and stately tower?

sp.speaker: 3. Beld.
sp.l: Thou seemest a stranger to ask such a question,
For where is not the tower of Darreine known?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: It may be called the tower of barren for ought I see, for here is none but are past children.

sp.speaker: 4. Beld.
sp.l: This is the rich and famous Darreine tower,
Where King Acrisius hath enclosed his daughter,
The beauteous Danae, famous through the world
For all perfections.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: O then 'tis here; I here I must unload.
Coming through Crete, the great King Jupiter
Entreated me to call here at this tower,
And to deliver you some special jewels,
Of high prized worth, for he would have his bounty
Renowned through all the earth. Down with your pack,
For here must we unload.

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.l: Jewels to us?

sp.speaker: 2. Beld.
sp.l: And from Jupiter?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Now gold prove thy true virtue. Thou canst all things and therefore this.

sp.speaker: 3. Beld.
sp.p: Comes he with presents, and shall he unpack at the gate? nay come into the porters lodge good pedlars.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: That lady hath some manners, she hath been well brought up I warrant her.

sp.speaker: 4. Beld.
sp.p: And I can tell thee pedlar, thou hast that courtesy that never any man yet found but the King Acrisius.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: You shall be well paid for your courtesy,
Here's first for you, for you, for, for you, for you.

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.l: Rare!

sp.speaker: 2. Beld.
sp.l: Admirable!

sp.speaker: 3. Beld.
sp.l: The best that e'er I saw!

sp.speaker: 4. Beld.
sp.l: I'll run and show mine to my lady.

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.p: Shut the gate for fear the King come, and if he ring clap the pedlars into some of you old rotten corners. And hath K. Jupiter bene at all this cost? he's a courteous prince, and bountiful. Keep you the pedlar company, my lady shall see mine too.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Mean you the Princess Danae? I have tokens from Jupiter to her too.

sp.speaker: 1. Bel.
sp.p: Run, run, you that have the best legs, and tell my lady. But have you any more of the same?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Have we quoth he? We have things about us, we have not showed yet, and that every one must not see, would make those few teeth in your head to water, I would have you think, I have worn too as well as my master.
sp.stage: Enter in state Danae with the beldames, looking upon three several jewels.

sp.speaker: 1. Bel.
sp.l: Yonder's my lady. Nay never be abashed pedlar,
There's a face will become thy jewels, as well as any face in
Crete or Argos either. Now your token.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I have lost it. 'tis my heart, beauty of angels,
Thou art o'er matched, earth may contend with heaven,
Nature thou hast to make one complete creature
Cheated even all mortality. This face
Hath robbed the morning of her blush, the lily
Of her blanched whiteness, and like theft committed
Upon my soul: she is all admiration.
But in her eyes I never saw perfect lustre.
There is no treasure upon earth but yonder.
She is! (O I shall lose myself)

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Nay sir, take heed you be not smelled out.

sp.speaker: Jupi.
sp.l: I am myself again.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Did he bestow these freely? Dana's guard
Are much indebted to King Jupiter.
If he have store we'll buy some for our use,
And wearing. They are wondrous beautiful,
Where's the man that brought them?

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.l: Here forsooth lady, hold up your head and blush not, my lady will not hurt thee, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: This jewel madam did King Jupiter
Command me to leave here for Danae.
Are you so styled?

sp.speaker: Danae.
sp.l: If sent to Danae,
'Tis due to me. And would the King of Crete,
knew with what gratitude we take his gift.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Madam he shall. Sirrah set open your pack,
And what the ladies like let them take freely.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Much have I heard of his renown in arms,
His generousness, his virtues, and his fullness
Of all that nature can bequeath to man.
His bounty I now taste, and I could wish,
Your ear were his, that I might let him know
What interest he hath in me to command,

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: His ear is mine, let me command you then.
Behold I am the Cretan, Jupiter,
That rate your beauty above all these gems.
What cannot love, what dares not love attempt?
Despite Acrisius and his armed guards,
Hither my love hath brought me to receive
Or life or death from you, only from you.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: We are amazed, and the large difference
Betwixt your name and habit, breeds in us
Fear and distrust. Yet if I censure freely
I needs must think that face and personage
Was never derived from baseness. And the spirit
To venture and to dare to court a Queen
I cannot style less than to be a King's.
Say that we grant you to be Jupiter,
What thence infer you?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: To love Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: So far as Jupiter loves Dana's honour,
So far will Danae love Jupiter.

sp.speaker: 2. Beld.
sp.l: We weight well upon my lady.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Madam you have not seen a clear stone,
For colour or for quickness.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Beware your ruin, if you beldames hear.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Sirrah show all your wares, and let those ladies best please themselves.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Not all at these years. I spy his knavery. Now would he have me keep them busied, whilst he courts the lady.

sp.speaker: 3, Beld.
sp.p: Doth my lady want nothing?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: As for example, here's a silver bodkin, this is to remove dandruff, and dig about the roots of your silver-haired fur. This is a tooth-picker, but you having no teeth, here is for you a coral to rub your gums. This is called a mask.

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.p: Gramercy for this, this is good to hide my wrinkles, I never see of these afore.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Then you have one wrinkle more behind. You that are dim eyed put this pitiful spectacle upon your nose.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: As I am son of Saturn, you have wrong
To be cooped up within a prison strong.
Your father like a miser cloisters you,
But to save cost: he's loath to pay your dower,
And therefore keeps you in this brazen tower.
What are you better to be beautiful,
When no man's eye can come to censure it?
What are sweet cates untasted? gorgeous clothes
Unworn? or beauty not beheld? yond beldames
With all the furrows in their wrinkled fronts
May claim with you like worth; eye and compare.
For eye to censure you none can, none dare.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: All this is true.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: O think you I would lie
(With any save Danae.) Let me buy
This jewel, your bright love, though rated higher
Than gods can give, or men in prayers desire.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: You covet that, which save the prince of Crete
None dares.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: That shows how much I love you (Sweet)
I come this beauty, this rare face to save,
And to redeem it from this brazen grave.
O do not from man's eye this beauty screen,
These rare perfections, which no earthly Queen
Enjoys save you: 'twas made to be admired.
The gods, the fates, and all things have conspired
With Jupiter, this prison to invade,
And bring it forth to that for which 'twas made.
Love Jupiter, whose love with yours shall meet,
and having born you hence, make at your feet
Kings lay their crowns, and mighty emperors kneel:
O had you but a touch of what I feel,
You would both love and pity.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Both I do.
But all things hinder, yet were Danae free,
She could affect the Cretan.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Now by thee
(For what I most affect, by that I swear)
I from this prison will bright Danae bear,
And in thy chamber will this night fast seal
This covenant made.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Which Danae must repeal.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: You shall not, by this kiss.

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.l: 'Tis good to have an eye.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Your nose hath not had these spectacles on yet.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: O Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: O Danae.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I must hence:
For if I stay, I yield: I'll hence, no more.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Expect me for I come.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Yond is my door,
Dare not to enter there. I will to rest.
Attendance.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Come I will.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: You had not best.

sp.speaker: 2. Beld.
sp.p: My lady calls. We have trifled the night till bedtime. Some attend the Princess: others see the pedlars packed out of the gate.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Will you thrust us out to seek our lodging at midnight. We have paid for our lodging, a man would think, we might have lain cheaper in any inn in Argos?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: This castle stands remote, no lodging near,
Spare us but any corner here below,
Be't but the inner porch, or the least staircase,
And we'll begone as early as you please.

sp.speaker: 2. Beld.
sp.p:
Consider all things, we have no reason to deny that.
What need we fear? alas they are but pedlars, and the greatest prince that breathes would be advised ere he durst presume to court the Princess Danae.

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.p: He court a Princess? he looks not with the face. Well pedlars, for this night take a nap upon some bench or other, and in the morning be ready to take thy yard in thy hand to measure me some stuff, and so to be gone before day. Well, goodnight, we must attend our Princess.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Gold and reward, thou art mighty, and haste power
O'er aged, young, the foolish, and the wise,
The chaste, and wanton, foul, and beautiful:
Thou art a god on earth, and canst all things.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Not all things, by your leave. All the gold in Crete cannot get one of you old crones with child. But shall we go sleep?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Sleep thou, for I must wake for Danae.
Hence cloud of baseness, thou hast done enough
To blear you beldames. When I next appear
To you bright goddess, I will shine in gold,
Decked in the high imperial robes of Crete,
And on my head the wreath of majesty:
For ornament is a prevailing thing,
And you bright Queen I'll now court like a King.
sp.stage: Enter the four old beldames, drawing out Dana's bed: she in it. They place four tapers at the four corners.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Command our eunuchs with their pleasing'st tunes
To charm our eyes to rest. Leave us all, leave us.
The god of dreams hath with his downy fan
Swept o'er our eyelids, and sits heavy on them.

sp.speaker: 1. Bel.
sp.p: Hey-ho, sleep may enter in at my mouth, if he be no bigger than a twopenny-loaf.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Then to your chambers, and let wakeless slumbers
Charm you in depth of silence and repose.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Good night to thee fair Danae.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Let music through this brazen fortress sound
Till all our hearts in depth of sleep be drowned.

sp.stage: Enter Jupiter crowned with his Imperiall robes.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Silence that now hath empire through the world
Express thy power and princedom. Charming sleep
Death's younger brother, show thyself as still-lesse
As death himself. None seem this night to live,
Save Jove and Danae. But that goddess won
Give them new life breathed with the morning sun,
You is the door, that in forbidding me
She bade me enter. Women's tongues and hearts
Have different tunes: for where they most desire,
Their hearts cry on. when their tongues bid retire.
All's whist, I hear the snorting beldames breathe
Soundness of sleep, none wakes save love and we
You bright imprisoned beauty to set free.
O thou more beauteous in thy nakedness
Then ornament can add to —
How sweetly doth she breathe? how well become
Imaginary deadness? But I'll wake her
Unto new life. This purchase I must win,
Heavens gates stand ope, and Jupiter will in.
Danae?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: 'Tis I, K. Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: What mean you prince? how dare you enter here?
Knowing if I but call, your life is doomed,
And all Crete's treasure cannot guard your person.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: You tell me now how much I rate your beauty,
Which to attain, I cast my life behind me,
As loved much less than you.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I'll love you too,
Would you but leave me.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Repentance I'd not buy
At that high rate, ten thousand times to die.
You are mine own, so all the fates have said.
And by their guidance come I to your bed.
The night, the time, the place, and all conspire
To make me happy in my long desire.
Acrisius eyes are charmed in golden sleep,
those beldames that were placed your bed to keep,
All drowned in Lethe (Save your downy bed,
White sheets, and pillow where you rest your head)
None hears or sees; and what can they devise,
When they (Heaven knows) have neither ears nor eyes.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Beshrew you sir, that for your amorous pleasure
Could thus sort all things, person, place and leisure.
Exclaim I could, and a loud uproar keep,
But that you say the crones are all asleep :
And to what purpose should I raise such fear,
My voice being soft, they fast, and cannot hear?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: They are deaf in rest, then gentle sweetly further,
If you should call, I thus your voice would murder,
And strangle with my kisses.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Kisses, tush.
I'll sink into my sheets, for I shall blush.
I'll dive into my bed.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: And I behind?
No: were't the ocean, such a gem to find,
I would dive after.
sp.stage: Jupiter puts out the lights and makes unready.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Good my lord forbear
What do you mean? (O heaven) is no man near,
If you will needs, for modesties chaste law,
Before you come to bed, the curtains draw,
But do not come, you shall not by this light,
If you but offer't, I shall cry out right.
O God, how hoarse am I, and cannot? fie
Danae thus naked and a man so nigh.
Pray leave me sir: he makes unready still,
Well I'll even wink, and then do what you will.
sp.stage: The bed is drawn in, and enter the clown new waked.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p:
I would I were out of this tower of brass, and from all these brazen faced beldames: if we should fall asleep, and the King come and take us napping, where were we? My lord stays long, and the night grows short, the thing you wot of hath cost him a simple sort of jewels. But if after all this cost, the thing you wot of would not do: if the pedlar should show himself
a piddler, he hath brought his hog's to a fair market. Fie upon it, what a snorting forward and backward these beldames keep? But let them sleep on, some in the house I am sure are awake, and stirring too, or I miss my aim. Well, here must I sit and wait the good hour, till the gate be open, and suffer my eyes to do that, which I am sure my cloak never will, that is, to take nap.
sp.stage: Enter Jupiter and Danae in her nightgown.

sp.speaker: Danae.
sp.l: Alas my lord I never loved till now,
And will you leave me?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Beauteous Queen I must,
But thus conditioned; to return again,
With a strong army to redeem you hence,
In spite of Argos, and Acrisius,
That dooms you to this bondage.

sp.speaker: Danae.
sp.l: Then farewell,
No sooner meet but part? Remember me:
For you great prince I never shall forget!
I fear you have left too sure a token with me
Of your remembrance.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Danae, be't a son,
It shall be ours when we have Argos won.

sp.speaker: Danae.
sp.l: But should you fail?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I sooner should forget
My name, my state, then fail to pay this debt,
The daystar 'gins t'appear, the beldame's stir,
Ready t'unlock the gate, fair Queen adieu.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: All men prove false, if Jove be found untrue.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: My man?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Some cloud to cover me, throw o'er my shoulders
Some shadow for this state, the crones are up,
And wait t'unprison us, nay quickly fellow.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Here my lord, cast your old cloak about you.
sp.stage: Enter the four beldames in haste.

sp.speaker: 1. Beld.
sp.p:
Where be these pedlars? nay quickly, for heaven's sake: the gate is open, nay when? farewell my honest friends,
and do our humble duties to the great King Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: King Jupiter shall know your gratitude, farewell.

sp.speaker: 2. Beld.
sp.l: Nay, when I say farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Farewell good Minivers.

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.l: Fair Danae doth his richest jewel wear.
That son of whom the oracle foretold
Which cost both mother and the grandsire dear
Whose fortunes further leisure shall unfold:
Think Jupiter returned to Crete in haste,
To levy arms for Danae's free release,
(But hindered) till the time be fully passed,
For Saturn once more will disturb his peace.
sp.stage: A dumb show. Enter King Troos and Ganimed with attendants, to him, Saturn makes suit for aid, shows the King his models, his inventions, his several metals, at the strangeness of which King Troos is moved, calls for drum, and colours, and marches with Saturn.
sp.l: The exiled Saturn by King Troos is aided,
Troos that gave Troy her name, and there reigned King,
Crete by the help of ganymede's invaded,
Even at that time when Jove should succours bring
To rescue Danae, and that warlike power,
Must now his native territories guard,
Which should have brought her from the brazen tower,
(For to that end his forces were prepared)
We grow now towards our port and wished bay,
Gentles your love, and Homer cannot stray.

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: Whence are these warlike preparations,
Made by the King our brother.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: 'Tis given out,
To conquer Argos. But my sister Juno
Suspects some amorous purpose in the King?

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: And blame her not, the fair Europa's rape,
Brought from Agenor, and the Cadmian rape,
Io the daughter of old Inachus,
Deflowered by him; the lovely Semele,
fair Leda daughter to King Tyndarus
With many more, may breed a just suspect,
Nor hath he spared fair Ceres' Queen of grain,
Who bore to him the bright Proserpina. (She
Such scapes may breed just fears, and what knows
But these are to surprise fair Danae.
sp.stage: Sound. Enter Jupiter, Archas, with drum and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Arm royal brothers, creet's too small an I'll,
To comprehend our greatness, we must add
Argos and Greece to our dominions.
And all the petty kingdoms of the earth,
Shall pay their homage unto Saturn's son,
This day we'll take a muster of our forces,
And forward make for Argos.

sp.speaker: Archas.
sp.l: All Arcadia
Assemble to this purpose.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Then set on.
The eagle in our ensign we'll display,
Jove and his fortunes guide us in our way.

sp.speaker: Melli.
sp.l: Whether intends the King this warlike (March?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: For Argos and Acrisius.

sp.speaker: Melli.
sp.l: Rather guard,
Your native confines, see upon your coast,
Saturn with thirty thousand Trojans landed
And in his aid King Troos and Ganymede.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: In never worse time could the tyrant come
Then now, to break my faith with Danae.
O beauteous love, I fear Acrisius' ire
Will with severest censure chastise thee,
And thou wilt deem me faithless and unkind
For promise-breach, (But what we must we must)
Come valiant lords, we'll first our own defend
Ere against foreign climes our arm extend.
sp.stage: Sound. Enter with drum and colours, King Troos, Saturn, Ganimed, with other lords and attendants.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Degenerate boys, base bastards, not my sons,
Behold the death we threatened in your cradles
We come to give you now. See here King Troos
in pity of deposed Saturn's wrongs,
Is come in person to chastise your pride,
And be the heaven's relentless justicer.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Not against Saturn as a father, we,
But as a murderer, lift our opposite hands.
Nature and heaven gives us this privilege,
To guard our lives 'gainst tyrants and invaders,
That claim we, as we're men, we would but live:
Then take not from us, what you cannot give.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Where hath not Saturn's fame abroad been spread
For many uses he hath given to man;
As navigation, tillage, archery,
Weapons and gold? yet you for all these uses
Deprive him of his kingdom.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: We but save
Our innocent bodies from th'abortive grave,

sp.speaker: Nept.
sp.l: We are his sons, let Saturn be content
To let us keep what heaven and nature lent.

sp.speaker: Gani.
sp.l: Those filial duties you so much forget
We come to teach you. Royal Kings to arms,
Give Ganymede the onset of this battle,
That being a son knows how to lecture them,
And chastise their transgressions.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Ganymede,
It shall be so, pour out your spleen and rage
On our proud issue. Let the thirsty soil
Of barren Crete quaff their degenerate bloods,
And surfeit in their sins. All Saturn's hopes
And fortunes are engaged upon this day.
It is our last, and all, be't our endeavour
To win't for ay, or else to lose it ever.
sp.stage: Alarm. The battles join, the Trojans are repulsed. Enter Troos and Saturn.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Our Trojans are repulsed, where's Ganymede?

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Amidst the throng of weapons, acting wonders.
Twice did I call aloud to have him fly,
And twice he swore he had vowed this day to die.

sp.speaker: Troos.
sp.l: Let's make up to his rescue.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Tush, 'tis vain.
To seek to save him we shall lose ourselves.
The day is lost, and Ganymede lost too
Without divine assistance. Hie my lord
Unto your ships, no safety lives a land,
Even to the ocean's margin we are pursued,
Then save yourself by sea.

sp.speaker: Troos.
sp.l: Crete thou hast won
My thirty thousand soldiers, and my son.
Come, let's to sea.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: To sea must Saturn too,
To whom all good stars are still opposite.
My crown I first bought with my infant's blood,
Not long enjoyed, till Titan wrested it;
Repurchased, and re-lost by Jupiter.
These horrid mischiefs that have crowned our brows,
Have bred in us such strange distemperature,
That we are grown dejected and forlorn.
Our blood is changed to ink, our hairs to quills,
Our eyes half buried in our queachy plots.
Consumptions and cold agues have devoured
And eat up all our flesh, leaving behind
Naught save the image of despair and death:
And Saturn shall to after ages be
That star, that shall infuse dull melancholy.
To Italy I'll fly, and there abide,
Till divine powers my place above provide.
sp.stage: Alarm. Enter ganimed'compassed in with soldiers, to them Jupiter, Neptune, Pluto, Archas Melliseus.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Yield noble Trojan, there's not in the field
One of thy nation lifts a hand save thee.

sp.speaker: Gani.
sp.l: Why that's my honour, when alone I stand
'Gainst thee and all the forces of thy land.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I love thy valour, and would woo thy friendship,
Go freely where thou wilt, and ransomless.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Why that's no gift: I am no prisoner,
and therefore owe no ransom, having breath,
Know I have vowed to yield to none save death.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I wish thee nobly Trojan, and since favour
Cannot attain thy love, I'll try conclusions,
And see if I can purchase it with blows.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Now speak'st thou like the noblest of my foes.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Stand all apart, and princes girt us round.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: I love him best, whose strokes can loudest sound.
sp.stage: Alarm, they fight, and losing their weapons embrace.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I have thee, and will keep thee.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: Not as prisoner.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: A prisoner to my love, else thou art free,
My bosom friend, for so I honour thee.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: I am conquered both by arms and courtesy.

sp.speaker: Nept.
sp.l: The day is ours, Troos and K. saturn's fled,
And Jupiter remains sole conqueror.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Peace with her golden wings hovers o'er Crete,
Frighting hence discord, and remorseless war:
Will Jupiter make up for Argos now?

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Winter draws on, the sea's unnavigable,
To transport an army. There attends without
A lord of Argos.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Bring him to our presence.
How stands it with the beauteous Danae?

sp.speaker: Arg. L.
sp.l: As one distressed by fate, and miserable.
Of K. Acrisius, and his fort of brass,
Danae's enclosure, and her beldame guard,
Who but hath heard? yet through these brazen walls
Love hath broke in, and made the maid a mother
Of a fair son, which when Acrisius heard,
Her female guard unto the fire he dooms,
His daughter, and the infant prince her son,
He puts into a mastless boat to sea,
To prove the rigor of the stormy waves.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Acrisius, Argos, and the world shall know
Jove hath been wronged in this: her further fortunes
Canst thou relate?

sp.speaker: Arges L.
sp.l: I can. As far as Naples
The friendly winds her mastless boat transports,
There succoured by a courteous fisherman
She's first relieved, and after that presented
To King Pelonnus, who at this time reigns:
Who ravished with her beauty, crowns her Queen,
And decks her with th'imperial robes of state.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: What we have scanted is supplied by fate.
Here then cease arms, and now court amorous peace
With solemn triumphs, and dear Ganymede,
Be henceforth called the friend of Jupiter.
And if the fates hereafter crown our brows
With divine honours, as we hope they shall,
We'll style thee by the name of cupbearer,
To fill us heavenly nectar, as fair Hebe
Shall do the like to Juno our bright Queen.
Here end the pride of our mortality.
Opinion, that makes gods, must style us higher.
The next you see us, we in state must shine,
Eternised with honours more divine.

sp.speaker: Homer.
sp.l: Of Danae Perseus was that night be got,
Perseus that fought with the Gorgonian shield,
Whose fortunes to pursue time suffers not.
For that, we have prepared an ampler field.
Likewise how Jove with fair Alcmena lay:
Of Hercules, and of his famous deeds:
How Pluto did fair Proserpine betray:
Of these my muse (Now travelled) next proceeds.
Yet to keep promise, ere we further wade,
The ground of ancient poems you shall see:
And how these (First born mortal) gods were made,
By virtue of divinest poesy.
The fates, to whom the heathen yield all power,
Whose dooms are writ in marble, to endure,
Have summoned Saturn's three sons to their tower,
To them the three dominions to assure
of heaven, of sea, of hell. How these are scanned,
Let none decide but such as understand.
sp.stage: Sound a dumb show. Enter the three fatal sisters, with a rock, a thread, and a pair of shears; bringing in a globe, in which they put three lots. Jupiter draws heaven: at which Iris descends and presents him with his eagle, crown and sceptre, and his thunderbolt. Jupiter first ascends upon the eagle, and after him Ganimed.
sp.l: To Jupiter doth high Olimpus fall.
Who thunder and the trisulc lightning bears
Dreaded of all the rest in general:
He on a princely eagle mounts the spheres,
sp.stage: Sound. Neptune draws the sea, is mounted upon a sea-horse; a robe and trident, with a crown are given him by the fates
sp.l: Neptune is made the lord of all the seas,
His mace a trident, and his habit blew.
He can make tempests, or the waves appease,
And unto him the seamen are still true.
sp.stage: Sound, thunder and tempest. Enter at 4 several::,,.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
